name: ğŸš A drone flying itself to take videos
explanation: Autonomous drones demonstrate Big Idea 1: Perception (using cameras and sensors to see obstacles) and Big Idea 2: Representation & Reasoning (building a map of their environment and planning paths in real-time).

name: ğŸ¥ The software that helps doctors spot diseases in scans
explanation: Medical AI uses Big Idea 1: Perception (analysing visual data from scans) and Big Idea 3: Learning (trained on thousands of images to recognise patterns of diseases like cancer or fractures).

name: ğŸ’¬ Chatbot that answers your questions online
explanation: Chatbots demonstrate Big Idea 4: Natural Interaction (understanding and generating human language) and Big Idea 3: Learning (trained on millions of conversations to generate relevant responses).

name: ğŸ® A video game that changes difficulty based on your skill
explanation: Adaptive difficulty uses Big Idea 3: Learning (monitoring your performance patterns) and Big Idea 2: Representation & Reasoning (maintaining a model of your skill level to adjust challenges dynamically).

name: âœï¸ An app that writes stories or poems for you
explanation: Generative AI writers use Big Idea 3: Learning (trained on vast amounts of text to understand language patterns) and Big Idea 4: Natural Interaction (producing human-like creative writing).

name: ğŸ­ Deepfake videos that swap faces realistically
explanation: Deepfakes use Big Idea 1: Perception (analysing facial features), Big Idea 3: Learning (trained on video data), and demonstrate Big Idea 5: Societal Impact (potential for misinformation and privacy concerns).

name: ğŸ“° A printed newspaper article
explanation: A newspaper is static printed text. It lacks Big Idea 1: Perception (can't sense the reader), Big Idea 3: Learning (can't adapt), and Big Idea 4: Natural Interaction (can't respond to you).

name: ğŸ¥« A hand-powered can opener
explanation: A can opener is a simple mechanical tool using leverage and a cutting wheel. None of the 5 Big Ideas apply - no perception, no learning, no reasoning, just human-powered mechanics.

name: ğŸ”¢ A regular calculator that only adds and subtracts
explanation: A basic calculator follows fixed mathematical rules - it lacks Big Idea 3: Learning (cannot learn new operations) and Big Idea 2: Representation & Reasoning (no adaptive problem-solving).

name: âŒš A mechanical wristwatch
explanation: A mechanical watch uses springs, gears, and an escapement mechanism. It's pure precision engineering with no computational intelligence - none of the 5 Big Ideas apply.

name: ğŸš´ A bike that you pedal to move
explanation: A bicycle converts pedalling energy into motion through gears and chains. It's entirely human-powered - no Big Idea 1: Perception, no Big Idea 3: Learning, no AI at all.

name: ğŸ“¸ A regular camera that uses film
explanation: A film camera uses optics and chemical processes to capture images. Unlike digital cameras with AI features, it has no Big Idea 1: Perception (in the AI sense) or Big Idea 3: Learning capabilities.

name: ğŸ’¡ A light bulb you turn on with a switch
explanation: A light bulb is a simple electrical circuit. When you flip the switch, electricity flows through to produce light - no Big Ideas apply, just basic physics.

name: ğŸš¥ A traffic light controlled by timers, not sensors
explanation: Timer-based traffic lights follow a fixed schedule regardless of conditions. They lack Big Idea 1: Perception (no sensing) and Big Idea 3: Learning (no adaptation to traffic patterns).

name: ğŸµ The app suggesting new songs after you listen to music
explanation: Music recommendation uses Big Idea 3: Learning (analysing your listening habits and finding patterns). This also demonstrates Big Idea 5: Societal Impact (influencing what music becomes popular).

name: ğŸ“¢ Online ads that seem to know what you like
explanation: Targeted advertising uses Big Idea 3: Learning (tracking behaviour to predict preferences). This raises Big Idea 5: Societal Impact concerns about privacy and manipulation.
